div1.p: Kean states that Reed's name should have appeared in the newspaper's article about yellow fever and briefly discusses Reed's and his assistant's work in conquering yellow fever. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to an Editor, May 19, 1921
div1.opener:
Boston 19 May 1921
Walter Reed and Yellow Fever.
div1.p:
No, Mr. Editor, the conquest of Yellow Fever was not made recently,
nor by Dr. Hideyo Noguchi, as stated in your Editorial this morning, although
there seems good ground to hope and believe that a cure for this fatal di-
sease has been found by the distinguished Japanese Pathologist. Yellow
Fever was conquered nearly twenty one years ago when by a wonderful series
of experiments on volunteers, Major Walter Reed and his assistants, Carroll,
Lazear and Agrimonte demonstrated that yellow fever was carried only by the
bite of a certain species of mosquito and not by personal contact or infected
clothing, or in any other way. Those experiments carried on with the appro-
val and financial assistance of the Military Governor, Leonard Wood, converted
the mosquito theory of Dr. Carlos J. Finlay “from a discredited hypothesis
into an established and accepted scientific fact.”.

The practical application of Reed's work by Gorgas cleared Havana
of yellow fever and made possible the sanitary conquest of the Isthmus of
Panama. It has for many years made safe our southern shores from this
dreaded enemy. It has been nineteen years since Harvard University con-
ferred a degree upon “Walter Reed, Army Surgeon, who gave to man control
over that dread disease Yellow Fever”, and these felicitous words of its
President, Doctor Charles Mr. ElliotW. Elliot, are carved on his tomb.

In that same year, 1902, Hon. Elihu Root, Secretary of War, recom-
mended to Congress that Major Reed, who was the guiding and controlling
mind in these investigations, be promoted to the grade of Colonel in the
Medical Department, but he died before this could be done.

President Roosevelt later sent a message to Congress transmitting
-2-
the official reports of his work and recommending a appropriation for
a monument to him in Washington. That Reed's name should not appear
in an article on the conquest of yellow fever in which its history is
touched upon and other names are mentioned, would appear to be an un-
gracious withholding of what is due to the fame of a great American.
div1.closer:
J. R. Kean. Boston, Mass.
May 19th, 1921.
